Award.AwardTitle: RI: Medium: Collaborative Research: Mobile Microrobot Platform for Advanced Manufacturing Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to create a flexible, micro-scale additive manufacturing platform utilizing a team of untethered micro-scale robots and modular, multifunctional building blocks to create smart micro-devices and structures. Externally applied magnetic fields are commonly used for the power and actuation of individual magnetic mobile microrobots. However, in order to achieve different behaviors from individual robots within a team of microrobots, there must be either significant variation in their design or in the magnetic control signals applied to each microrobot.

The intellectual merit of this research, therefore, lies in the novel approach to create a specialized magnetic potential field generating substrate from MEMS-fabricated planar microcoils and the related control methodology to enable truly independent control of multiple mobile microrobots. Thus, the research objectives of the proposal are: the design and fabrication of the micro-coils and related control electronics; motion control for mobile magnetic microrobot swarms; and magnetic microrobot and modular component design and fabrication, based on specialized micro-components with various material properties and functions.

Successful completion of the objectives will result in a transformative mobile microrobot swarm platform capable of executing various advanced additive manufacturing tasks. Potential applications include very high-density energy storage, high strain actuation, energy harvesting, very low power communications devices, and composite structures with integrated sensors. Further broader impacts of this project reside in disseminating the research output in industry and academia along with an educational agenda spanning related outreach activities from the K-12 through graduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mobile microrobots offer unprecedented capabilities for observing and interacting with the world that are not possible with conventional macro-scale systems. A critical issue in the design of mobile microrobots is the generation of wireless power and methods of converting that power into locomotion. Previous researchers have successfully used externally applied magnetic fields for the power and actuation of individual magnetic mobile microrobots. In the case of multiple microrobots, all the robots in the workspace will be exposed to identical control signals. Thus, in order to achieve different behaviors from individual robots needed for manufacturing tasks, there must be either significant variation in their design or in the magnetic control signals applied to each microrobot. In order to achieve these desired behaviors, this project accomplished the following:

  • Design of Specialized Substrate and Control System: A specialized local-magnetic field generating substrate and associated electronics were developed to produce truly decoupled, individual control of multiple micro-scale for the first time. A few different iterations of the substrate were fabricated using custom designed multi-layer printed circuit boards and custom control electronics.
  • Motion Control Algorithms for Mobile Microrobot Swarms: Real magnetic potential field navigation controls were developed for individual and swarm control of the microrobots by the control substrate. Cases for single and multiple robots with static and dynamic obstacles were studied in the presence of system uncertainties.
  • Magnetic Microrobot Design: The design, manufacture, and characterization of various types of magnetic microrobots were explored and experimentally validated.  The novel use of a tail on the magnetic microrobot designs allowed for orientation control need to perform autonomous micromanipulation tasks.  A system independently controlling a team of four microrobots was experimentally demonstrated along with temporal micro-assembly tasks using micro-scale Lego-like components, path planning in the presence of obstacles and other robots, and trajectory following.  

There are many broader impacts for the proposed flexible microrobot manufacturing platform. Through the use of modular blocks with various properties and functionalities, a variety of micro-scale systems, devices, and sensor are possible. For example, this technology will enable very high-density energy storage, high strain actuation, energy harvesting, very low power communications, and low power/high sensitivity sensors to be integrated into composite structures with integrated bearings and joints. Microrobot manufacturing swarms, manipulating and assembling these multi-functional building blocks, is the enabling technology that would make this possible.  Through the course of this project, it generated training and profession development opportunities for 2 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, and 3 post-docs.  They all supported various outreach activities and lab tours to numerous K-12 students to inspire them to work in the STEM fields.
